Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Acting rationally: The rational agent approach ‚Ä¢ An agent is just something that acts. ‚Ä¢ A rational agent is one that acts so as to achieve the best outcome or, when there is uncertainty, the best expected outcome. ‚Ä¢ In the ‚Äúlaws of thought‚Äù approach to AI, the emphasis was on correct inferences. ‚Ä¢ Making correct inferences is sometimes part of being a rational agent, and ‚Ä¢ There are also ways of acting rationally that cannot involve inference. ‚Ä¢ Rational behavior: doing the right thing ‚Ä¢ The right thing: that which is expected to maximize goal achievement, given the available information ‚Ä¢ Doing the right thing doesn't necessarily always involve thinking but thinking should be in the service of rational action Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Downloaded by: stuvia7feva | stuvia.7feva@simplelogin.com Distribution of this document is illegal Want to earn R13,625 per year? Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Good Behavior: Rationality ‚Ä¢ A rational agent is one that does the right thing. ÔÉ® What is the right thing? ‚Ä¢ A sequence of actions causes the environment to go through a sequence of states. ‚Ä¢ If the sequence is desirable, then the agent has performed well. ‚Ä¢ The notion of desirability is captured by a performance measure that evaluates any given sequence of environment states. ‚Ä¢ A rational agent chooses whichever action maximizes the expected value of the performance measure given the percept sequence. Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Rationality: omniscience, learning, and autonomy ‚Ä¢ An omniscient (perfect) agent knows the actual outcome of its actions and can act accordingly; but perfection is impossible in reality. ‚Ä¢ Rationality is NOT the same as perfection. ‚Ä¢ Rationality maximizes expected performance, while perfection maximizes actual performance. ‚Ä¢ A rational agent not only to gather information (exploration) but also to learn as much as possible from what it perceives. ‚Ä¢ An agent relies on the prior knowledge of its designer rather than on its own percepts, we say that the agent lacks autonomy. A rational agent should be autonomous. ‚Ä¢ Rational ÔÉ® exploration, learning, autonomy Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Downloaded by: stuvia7feva | stuvia.7feva@simplelogin.com Distribution of this document is illegal Want to earn R13,625 per year? Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Environment types ‚Ä¢ The environment type largely determines the agent design. ‚Ä¢ Fully observable vs. partially observable: ‚Ä¢ If an agent‚Äôs sensors give it access to the complete state of the environment at each point in time, then task environment is called as fully observable. ‚Ä¢ Fully observable environments are convenient because the agent need not maintain any internal state to keep track of the world. ‚Ä¢ An environment might be partially observable because of noisy and inaccurate sensors. ‚Ä¢ Single agent vs. multi agent: ‚Ä¢ One or more agents. Solving a crossword puzzle is a single agent environment. ‚Ä¢ Chess is a competitive multi agent environment because an agent tries to maximize its performance while minimizing the performance of other agent. ‚Ä¢ Taxi-driving partially cooperative multi agent environment because avoiding collisions maximizes all agents‚Äô performances. Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Environment types ‚Ä¢ Deterministic vs. stochastic: ‚Ä¢ If the next state of the environment is completely determined by the current state and the action executed by the agent, then the environment is deterministic; otherwise, it is stochastic. ‚Ä¢ Episodic vs. sequential: ‚Ä¢ In an episodic task environment, the agent‚Äôs experience is divided into atomic episodes. In each episode the agent receives a percept and then performs a single action. The next episode does not depend on the actions taken in previous episodes. ‚Ä¢ In sequential environments, on the other hand, the current decision could affect all future decisions. Chess and taxi driving are sequential: in both cases, short-term actions can have long- term consequences. ‚Ä¢ Static vs. dynamic: ‚Ä¢ If the environment can change while an agent is deliberating, then we say the environment is dynamic for that agent; otherwise, it is static. ‚Ä¢ Discrete vs. continuous: ‚Ä¢ The discrete/continuous distinction applies to the state of the environment. ‚Ä¢ Chess is discrete; Taxi-driving continuous Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Downloaded by: stuvia7feva | stuvia.7feva@simplelogin.com Distribution of this document is illegal Want to earn R13,625 per year? Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Problem-Solving Agent ‚Ä¢ A problem-solving agent is a goal-based agent and use atomic representations. ‚Ä¢ In atomic representations, states of the world are considered as wholes, with no internal structure visible to the problem solving algorithms. ‚Ä¢ Intelligent agents are supposed to maximize their performance measure. Achieving this is sometimes simplified if the agent can adopt a goal and aim at satisfying it. ‚Ä¢ Problem formulation is the process of deciding what actions and states to consider, given a goal. ‚Ä¢ The process of looking for a sequence of actions that reaches the goal is called search. ‚Ä¢ A search algorithm takes a problem as input and returns a solution in the form of an action sequence. ‚Ä¢ Once a solution is found, the carrying actions it recommends is called the execution phase. ‚Ä¢ A problem-solving agent has three phases: ‚Ä¢ problem formulation, searching solution and executing actions in the solution. Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Problem-Solving Agent Well-defined problems A problem can be defined by five components: ‚Ä¢ initial state, actions, transition model, goal test, path cost. INITIAL STATE: The initial state that the agent starts in. ACTIONS: A description of the possible actions available to the agent. ‚Ä¢ Given a particular state s, ACTIONS(s) returns the set of actions that can be executed in s. ‚Ä¢ Each of these actions is applicable in s. TRANSITION MODEL: A description of what each action does is known as the transition model ‚Ä¢ A function RESULT(s,a) that returns the state that results from doing action a in state s. ‚Ä¢ The term successor to refer to any state reachable from a given state by a single ‚Ä¢ The state space of the problem is the set of all states reachable from the initial state by any sequence of actions. ‚Ä¢ The state space forms a graph in which the nodes are states and the links between nodes are actions. ‚Ä¢ A path in the state space is a sequence of states connected by a sequence of actions. Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Problem-Solving Agent Well-defined problems GOAL TEST: The goal test determines whether a given state is a goal state. PATH COST: A path cost function that assigns a numeric cost to each path. ‚Ä¢ The problem-solving agent chooses a cost function that reflects its own performance measure. ‚Ä¢ The cost of a path can be described as the sum of the costs of the individual actions along the path. ‚Ä¢ The step cost of taking action a in state s to reach state s‚Ä≤ is denoted by c(s, a, s‚Ä≤). ‚Ä¢ A SOLUTION to a problem is an action sequence that leads from the initial state to a goal state. ‚Ä¢ Solution quality is measured by the path cost function, and an OPTIMAL SOLUTION has the lowest path cost among all solutions. Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Problem Example vacuum world States: ‚Ä¢ The state is determined by both the agent location and the dirt locations. ‚Ä¢ The agent is in one of two locations, each of which might or might not contain dirt. ‚Ä¢ Thus, there are 2 √ó 22 = 8 possible world states. Initial state: Any state can be designated as the initial state. Actions: Each state has just three actions: Left, Right, and Suck. Transition model: ‚Ä¢ The actions have their expected effects, except that moving Left in the leftmost square, moving Right in the rightmost square, and Sucking in a clean square have no effect. ‚Ä¢ The transition model defines a state space. Goal test: This checks whether all the squares are clean. Path cost: Each step costs 1, so the path cost is the number of steps in the path. Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Searching for Solutions ‚Ä¢ A solution is an action sequence and search algorithms considers various possible action sequences. ‚Ä¢ The possible action sequences starting at the initial state form a search tree with the initial state at the root; ‚Ä¢ The branches are actions and the nodes correspond to states in the state space of the problem. ‚Ä¢ Expanding the current state is application of each legal action to the current state and generation of a new set of states. ‚Ä¢ The current state is the parent node, newly generated states are child nodes ‚Ä¢ Leaf node is a node with no children in the tree. ‚Ä¢ The set of all leaf nodes available for expansion at any given point is called the frontier. ‚Ä¢ Search algorithms all share this basic structure; they vary primarily according to how they choose which state to expand next: search strategy. Stuvia.com - The study-notes marketplace Informal Description of Graph Search Algorithms ‚Ä¢ To avoid exploring redundant paths is to remember them. ‚Ä¢ Explored set (also known as closed list) remembers every expanded node. ‚Ä¢ The frontier needs to be stored in such a way that search algorithm can easily choose next node to expand according to its preferred strategy. ‚Ä¢ The appropriate data structure for this is a queue. ‚Ä¢ Queues are characterized by the order in which they store the inserted nodes. ‚Ä¢ First-in, first-out or FIFO queue, which pops the oldest element of the queue; (QUEUE) ‚Ä¢ Last-in, first-out or LIFO queue (also known as STACK), which pops the newest element ‚Ä¢ PRIORITY QUEUE, which pops the element of the queue with the highest priority according to some ordering function. ‚Ä¢ The explored set can be implemented with a hash table to allow efficient checking for repeated states.
